questions.question: A microbiologist was studying worms infecting the human body and discovered a flat, leaf-like species with an incomplete digestive system. To which of the following classes does this organism most likely belong?
questions.explanation: they have a mouth and a simple gut but no anus. Mode of Infection Examples Infective Form Hosts Ingestion of contaminated water/vegetation Liver and intestinal flukes (e.g., Fasciola hepatica , Fasciolopsis buski ) Metacercaria Definitive: Humans Intermediate: Snails (primary), vegetation (secondary) Consumption of raw/undercooked fish/crustaceans Lung and liver flukes (e.g., Clonorchis sinensis , Paragonimus westermani ) Metacercaria Definitive: Humans Intermediate: Snails (primary), fish/crustaceans (secondary) Skin penetration Blood flukes (e.g., Schistosoma species) Cercaria Definitive: Humans Intermediate: Snails Cestode ( Option A) : Cestodes, or tapeworms, are flatworms as well, but they are typically segmented and lack a digestive system entirely. Instead, they absorb nutrients directly through their body surface. Nematode (Option B) : Nematodes, also known as roundworms, have a cylindrical, unsegmented body and a complete digestive system. Annelid (Option D ): Annelids, or segmented worms, include earthworms and leeches. They have a segmented body and a complete digestive system. Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page: 143,144. Apurba S Sastry Essentials of Practical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page: 452,453. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK8282/

questions.question: Match the following trematode species with their primary habitat in the primary host. Trematode Species Primary Habitat 1. Fasciolopsis buski a. Bile ducts 2. Schistosoma mansoni b. Small intestine 3. Clonorchis sinensis c. Mesenteric veins 4. Paragonimus westermani d. Lungs
questions.explanation: c. Mesenteric veins 3. Clonorchis sinensis a. Bile ducts 4. Paragonimus westermani d. Lungs Habitats of common trematode species Trematode Group Species Primary Habitat Intestinal Trematodes Fasciolopsis buski Small intestine Liver Trematodes Fasciola hepatica Liver and bile ducts Clonorchis sinensis Bile ducts Opisthorchis viverrini Bile ducts Lung Trematodes Paragonimus westermani Lungs Blood Trematodes Schistosoma mansoni Mesenteric veins Schistosoma haematobium Veins around the bladder Schistosoma japonicum Mesenteric veins Pancreatic Trematodes Eurytrema pancreaticum (rare) Pancreatic ducts Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page: 143,144. Apurba S Sastry Essentials of Practical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page: 453.

questions.question: Which of the following trematode species does not produce operculated eggs?
questions.explanation: are oval and have a characteristic spine , making them easily distinguishable from those of other trematodes. General Characteristics of Trematode Eggs Size and Shape: Trematode eggs vary in size, typically ranging from small (20-30 µm) to large (up to 150 µm). The shape can be oval, round, or slightly asymmetrical. Operculum: Many trematode eggs have an operculum, a lid-like structure, that facilitates the release of larvae (miracidia) upon contact with water. Spines or Knobs: Certain species, particularly Schistosoma, have distinctive spines (terminal or lateral) used for species identification. Embryonation: Some eggs, such as those of Clonorchis and Opisthorchis, are embryonated upon excretion, meaning they contain a developed miracidium ready to hatch. Shell Color: Eggs often have a golden-brown appearance due to bile staining as they pass through the liver and intestines in many host species. Trematode Key Features Sample Type Schistosoma haematobium Terminal spine at one end; found in urine Urine Schistosoma mansoni Lateral spine on one side Stool Schistosoma japonicum Rudimentary spine, often difficult to see Stool Fasciola hepatica Operculum at one end; golden-brown Stool Paragonimus westermani Thick shell, operculum present Sputum/Stool Clonorchis sinensis Thickened rim around operculum; knob opposite operculum; embryonated Stool Opisthorchis spp. Prominent operculum, embryonated Stool

questions.question: A 28-year-old man presents with complaints of abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and a recent onset of fatigue. He mentions that he has been working near freshwater lakes in an endemic region. A stool sample reveals Schistosoma eggs. Which of the following statements about Schistosoma species is incorrect?

options.A: The intermediate host for all Schistosoma species is a snail.
options.B: The life cycle of Schistosoma includes redia and metacercaria larvae.
options.C: Schistosoma japonicum primarily inhabits the superior mesenteric vein.
options.D: Schistosoma infections occur through skin penetration by cercaria larvae

questions.explanation: such as miracidia and sporocysts followed by cercariae. Schistosoma (Blood Fluke): Species Schistosoma haematobium (Africa, Near East, Middle East, India) Schistosoma mansoni (Africa, South America) Schistosoma japonicum (China, Japan, Far East) Habitat S. haematobium: Veins of vesical and pelvic plexuses S. mansoni: Inferior mesenteric vein S. japonicum: Superior mesenteric vein (Option C) Definitive Host Man Intermediate Host Snail (Option A) Mode of Infection Skin penetration by cercaria (Option D) Infective form Cercaria larva Eggs Has characteristic lateral spine. Larva Has following stages: (Option B) Miracida Sporocysts Cercaria: Has elongated ovoid body and forked tail. Adult worm Sexes are separate . Has 2 muscular suckers: Oral and ventral sucker Gynecophoric canal begins behind the ventral sucker, where the female worm is held. Life Cycle:

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents with painless hematuria and dysuria after returning from a trip to the Middle East. He reports swimming in freshwater lakes during his stay. Laboratory tests reveal eggs with a characteristic terminal spine in the urine. Which of the following is a potential complication of this condition?

options.C: Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

questions.explanation: terminal spine, point toward a diagnosis of schistosomiasis caused by Schistosoma haematobium, which is associated with an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Clinical Features of Varoius Schistosoma Species: S. Haematobium S. Mansoni S. Japonicum Swimmer’s itch Painless hematuria, dysuria, proteinuria Urinary bladder carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma > Transitional cell carcinoma (Option C) Calculus formation Chronic cystitis Swimmer’s itch Katayama fever: High fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy Intestinal bilharziasis: Abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea (Option D) Portal hypertension and periportal fibrosis. Severe swimmer’s itch Katayama fever in acute phase Colicky abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, anemia CNS involvement: Severe epileptic seizures (Option A) Lung involvement: Cor pulmonale,pulmonary hypertension. Parasites associated with Malignancy: Parasite Associated Malignancy Schistosoma haematobium Urinary bladder cancer Schistosoma japonicum Colorectal cancer, metastatic lung cancer Schistosoma mansoni Colorectal cancer, hepatocellular carcinoma Opisthorchis viverrini Clonorchis sinensis Opisthorchis felineus Cholangiocarcinoma Plasmodium species Burkitt lymphoma Strongiloides stercoralis HTLV-1 induced lymphoma/leukemias Reference: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page 145,148,150 Apurba S Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 456 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC88908/ https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/schistosoma https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9513158/ https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/immunology-and-microbiology/schistosoma-mekongi#

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea after frequent exposure to freshwater while traveling in Africa. Stool examination reveals the presence of eggs with a characteristic lateral spine. Which of the following is inconsistent with this condition?

options.C: Swimmer’s itch due to cercarial penetration
options.D: Neurological deficit due to egg embolization

questions.explanation: stool examination revealing eggs with a lateral spine which is characteristic of schistosoma mansoni . Painless hematuria and dysuria are more associated with urogenital schistosomiasis (Schistosoma haematobium), not intestinal schistosomiasis. Schistosomiasis/ Bilharziasis: Intestinal Schistosomiasis Urogenital Schistosomiasis Caused by S. intercalatum, S. japonicum, S. mansoni and S. mekongi Swimmer’s itch/Cercarial dermatitis (Option C ruled out) Katayama fever (S. Japonicum > S. Mansoni): Serum sickness like illness with high fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy Abdominal pain, bloody dysentery Portal hypertension Microabscess, granuloma, hyperplasia and eventually fibrosis of intestinal wall Periportal fibrosis (clay pipestem fibrosis) (Option B ruled out) Lung involvement: Cor pulmonale CNS involvement: Severe epileptic seizures Neurological deficit: Egg embolization (Option D ruled out) Caused by S. haematobium Swimmer’s itch/Cercarial dermatitis Pulmonary symptoms: Cough, mild fever Painless hematuria Dysuria (Option A) Proteinuria Pseudoabscess in bladder Fibrosis of vesical mucosa and formation of egg granuloma (sandy patches) Recurrent UTI Hydronephrosis Hydroureter Urinary bladder carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma > Transitional cell carcinoma Chronic cystitis Calculus formation Reference: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page 145,148,150 https://www.emro.who.int/h ealth-topics/schistosomiasis/#:~:text=Intestinal%20schistosomiasis%20can%20present%20with,kidney%20damage %20in%20advanced%20cases https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/nursing-and-health-professions/neuroschistosomiasis#

questions.question: A patient is suspected to have schistosomiasis. Microscopic examination of urine and stool is conducted, including acid-fast staining. Which of the following Schistosoma species is not acid-fast positive?
questions.explanation: Schistosoma: Non-operculated egg Stool Microscopy: S. mansoni (114 to 180 µm long): Ova with a lateral spine , acid-fast stain positive (Option D) S. japonicum (70-100 µm long): Ova with a lateral knob, acid-fast stain positive (Option C) S. intercalatum (140-240 µm): Ova with a terminal spine , acid-fast stain positive (Option B) Urine Microscopy of S. Haematobium (110-170 µm long): Ova with a terminal spine Acid fast stain negative (Option A) Treatment: Praziquantel (single oral dose 40 mg/kg): Drug of choice

questions.question: The given image was seen during a microscopic examination of a sputum sample from a patient with a cough with associated hemoptysis. Identify the false statement.

options.B: It is the infective form of the causative agent
options.C: The mode of transmission is via ingestion
options.D: Crabs are second intermediate hosts, and humans are the definitive hosts

questions.explanation: Paragonimus westermani also known as the lung fluke in which the infective form is the metacercarea (larva) and not the operculated eggs . Paragonimus westermani / Lung fluke This is a trematode which is also known as the oriental lung fluke. It causes endemic hemoptysis in humans. Epidemiology : Global Prevalence: Approximately 22 million cases and 10 species infect humans. Key Regions: World: Predominantly found in the Far East (Korea, Japan, Taiwan, China, Philippines). India: Endemic in Northeast states, particularly Manipur (prevalence: 6.7%). Morphology Adult worms: Leaf-like shape. Eggs: Operculated eggs. (Option A) They are oval and golden brown. Size: 80–120 µm × 45–65 µm. Eggs are unembryonated when laid. Larvae: Five developmental stages. Hosts (Option D) Definitive host: Humans. Intermediate hosts : First: Snails. Second: Crabs or crayfish. Transmission Infection occurs through ingestion of infected crabs/crayfishes carrying metacercariae (infective larvae). Larvae penetrate the intestinal wall, enter the peritoneal cavity, and migrate to the lungs. Adult worms produce eggs, which are expelled through sputum (commonly) or feces. Pathogenicity and clinical features Pulmonary paragonimiasis: It causes eosinophilic granulomatous inflammation and cyst formation around worms, often in the right lung. Symptoms: Productive cough with brownish, blood-tinged sputum (offensive, fishy odor). Possible frank hemoptysis and peripheral blood eosinophilia . Chronic infections may lead to bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pneumonia, or lung abscesses. Extrapulmonary paragonimiasis: Worms may migrate to sites like the liver, spleen, abdominal wall , and occasionally the brain. Forms: Cerebral Paragonimiasis: this is a severe form. Cutaneous Paragonimiasis: Migratory subcutaneous nodules and larva migrans. Life cycle: Definite host: Humans. First intermediate host: Snails. Second intermediate hosts: Crabs or crayfish. (option D) Mode of transmission:

questions.question: Match the following parasites with their correct common names and source of infection: Parasite Common Name and Source of Infection Fasciolopsis buski a) Small intestinal fluke; Freshwater fish 2. Metagonimus yokogawai b) Chinese liver fluke; Freshwater fish 3. Fasciola hepatica c) Giant intestinal fluke; Freshwater plants 4. Clonorchis sinensis d) Colonic fluke; Freshwater plants 5. Gastrodiscoides hominis e) Sheep liver fluke; Freshwater plants
questions.explanation: Host Fasciola hepatica Sheep liver fluke Liver and biliary passages of definitive host Sheep, goat, cattle and man Snail Freshwater plants Fasciola gigantica Giant liver fluke or tropical fluke Clonorchis sinensis Chinese liver fluke Biliary tract, sometimes pancreatic duct of humans Human Snail Freshwater fish Intestinal Flukes Common Name Habitat Definitive Host First Intermediate Host Second Intermediate Host Fasciolopsis buski Giant intestinal fluke Duodenum or jejunum of pigs and man Man and pigs Snails Freshwater plants Metagonimus yokogawai Small intestinal fluke Small intestine of definitive host Humans, pigs, dogs, cats and pelicans. Snail Freshwater fish Heterophyes heterophyes Small intestinal fluke Small intestine of definitive host Humans, cats, dogs, foxes and other fish-eating mammals Snail Freshwater fish Gastrodiscoides hominis Colonic fluke Human large intestine Man, pigs and monkey Snail Freshwater plants Reference: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Pages 150,151,152,154, 156,157,158,159,160 https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/metagonimiasis/index.html# https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/opisthorchiasis/index.html# https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/immunology-and-microbiology/fasciola-gigantica# https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/echinostomiasis/index.html https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/echinostoma#

questions.question: A 56-year-old male patient presents with jaundice, weight loss, and pruritus. Imaging studies reveal a mass in the bile duct, and ERCP demonstrates strictures and dilated bile ducts. Further investigations suggest an infectious etiology. Which of the following evolutionary stages of an organism and secondary intermediate host is responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: ducts. These larvae encyst in fish and are transmitted to humans through the consumption of undercooked fish , leading to inflammation and strictures in the biliary system. Clonorchis sinensis " Chinese liver fluke ": Parasite Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke) is a parasitic fluke that causes clonorchiasis in humans. Transmission Acquired by consuming undercooked or raw freshwater fish contaminated with the parasite. Morphology Adult Fluke: Flat, leaf-shaped; 10-25 mm in length and 3-5 mm in width. Tapered anterior end and rounded posterior end. Body covered with tegument bearing tiny spines. Two suckers: oral sucker at the anterior end and ventral sucker (acetabulum) positioned further down. Egg: Oval, operculated (with a lid-like structure), yellow-brown in colour. Distinct operculum at the anterior end and a small knob at the abopercular end. Life Cycle 1. Egg Release: Infected individuals excrete eggs in feces, contaminating freshwater sources. 2. Snail Host: Eggs ingested by freshwater snails (first intermediate host) hatch and develop through stages: miracidia, sporocysts, rediae, and finally cercariae. 3. Fish Host: Cercariae are released from the snail into the water, where they seek and penetrate freshwater fish (second intermediate host), encysting as metacercariae in the fish’s muscle or skin. 4. Human Host: Humans become infected by consuming raw or undercooked fish containing metacercariae, which excyst, migrate to the bile ducts, and mature into adult flukes. 5. Egg Laying: Adult flukes in bile ducts lay eggs that are excreted in feces, completing the life cycle. Presentation Features Acute Infection: Symptoms are often mild or absent. When present, it may include right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, fatigue, nausea, diarrhea, and eosinophilia. Chronic Infection: Long-term infections may lead to biliary obstruction, cholangitis, cholecystitis, or gallstones. Severe cases can cause liver cirrhosis, bile duct cancer ( cholangiocarcinoma ), and pancreatitis. Investigations 1. Stool Examination: Microscopy for characteristic eggs in stool samples (primary diagnostic method; eggs may be scarce in light infections). 2. Duodenal Aspirate/Bile Examination: Detects eggs in bile samples or duodenal aspirates, helpful when stool examination is inconclusive. 3. Serology: Blood tests to detect antibodies or antigens specific to Clonorchis sinensis. 4. Imaging: Ultrasound may show biliary dilatation or thickening, suggestive of chronic infection. CT/MRI useful for identifying biliary obstruction, liver abnormalities, or cholangiocarcinoma in severe cases. Management Praziquantel (Drug of Choice): Dosage 25 mg/kg orally, three times daily for 2 days. Alternative: Albendazole can be used if Praziquantel is contraindicated.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, jaundice, nausea, and a history of consuming contaminated water and aquatic vegetation while camping near a river. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant and mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin, and stool examination reveals operculated eggs (as shown in the image). What is the best management strategy for this patient?
questions.explanation: acquired through the consumption of contaminated water or aquatic vegetation. The operculated eggs found in the stool confirm this diagnosis. Fasciola hepatica infection is typically treated with Triclabendazole, a broad-spectrum anthelmintic that is effective against various liver flukes. Fasciola hepatica Fasciola hepatica, commonly known as the liver fluke, is a parasitic trematode (flatworm) that primarily infects the livers of various mammals, including humans. It causes the disease fascioliasis, leading to liver damage, biliary obstruction, and inflammatory reactions. Morphology Adult Fluke: Shape: Leaf-shaped, flat, and broad. Size: Approximately 2-3 cm in length and 1 cm in width. Color: Typically brown or grey. Distinctive Features: Cone-shaped anterior end.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and significant weight loss over the past month. He recently traveled to a rural area where he ingested aquatic plants while swimming in a freshwater lake. On examination, he exhibits pallor and mild abdominal tenderness. A stool examination reveals the presence of eggs. Considering his symptoms and recent travel history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Fasciolopsis buski, a intestinal fluke commonly associated with aquatic plants ingestion. Parasite Fasciolopsis buski (Giant Intestinal Fluke) is a parasitic trematode infecting the small intestine of humans and pigs, causing fasciolopsiasis, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms and malabsorption. Morphology Adult: Size: 20-75 mm in length. Color: Brownish or yellowish. Structure: Characteristic oral sucker at the anterior end for attachment; ventral sucker further down aids in feeding. Egg: Size: 130-140 micrometres in length, 80-85 micrometres in width. Shape: Elliptical or oval. Operculum: Possesses a lid-like structure at one end that opens when the egg is ready to release larvae. Life Cycle Egg Stage: Eggs released in feces of infected humans or pigs, reach freshwater
